titles.title: Head of Christ Crowned with Thorns

makers.displaydate: 1500–1550; born Nuremberg, Germany; died Frankfurt am Main, Germany
makers.displaymaker: attributed to Hans Sebald Beham, 1500–1550; born Nuremberg, Germany; died Frankfurt am Main, Germany

makers.displaydate: 1471–1528; born and died Nuremberg, Germany; active Venice, Italy, and Nuremburg
makers.displaymaker: formerly attributed to Albrecht Dürer, 1471–1528; born and died Nuremberg, Germany; active Venice, Italy, and Nuremburg

texts.textentryhtml: Throughout the Middle Ages, artists created paintings depicting what was referred to as “Veronica’s veil.” The image derives from what is believed to be the blood- and sweat-soaked impression Christ’s tortured face left on the cloth with which Veronica, a woman from Jerusalem, had comforted him on his way to Calvary. The veil was venerated as an acheiropoetos, an image made without human hands and hence the only vera icon, or true image, of Christ. In this monumental woodcut, the divine apparition and its representation seem to merge as Christ’s life-size face floats on an otherwise empty sheet, as if the sheet were the veil itself. Like the mythical cloth, the woodcut is the result of a contact—the impression left by the ink-covered wooden matrix on the paper. This work is thought to be by Hans Sebald Beham, a follower of the more celebrated German artist Albrecht Dürer (1471–1528), whose monogram was added later to enhance the print’s value.

[Antiquariat Weidhas, Berlin, in 1844 (according to pencil inscription on the verso)]. [Guy van Hoorebeke, Brussels]; purchased by Sam Josefowitz, Pully (Switzerland); thence by descent;[C.G. Boerner, New York]; purchased by Princeton University Art Museum, 2022.

displaymaker: attributed to Hans Sebald Beham, 1500–1550; born Nuremberg, Germany; died Frankfurt am Main, Germany | formerly attributed to Albrecht Dürer, 1471–1528; born and died Nuremberg, Germany; active Venice, Italy, and Nuremburg
caption: Attributed to Hans Sebald Beham (1500–1550; born Nuremberg, Germany; died Frankfurt am Main, Germany), formerly attributed to Albrecht Dürer (1471–1528; born and died Nuremberg, Germany; active Venice, Italy, and Nuremburg), Head of Christ Crowned with Thorns, ca. 1520, printed 1550–1600. Woodcut; 43.2 × 32.4 cm (block), 50.8 × 34 cm (sheet). Museum purchase, Laura P. Hall Memorial Fund (2022-250)
